story:
Once upon a time, in a small village nestled in the heart of the Andes, there lived a kind and curious little boy named Diego. Diego's father was a skilled craftsman, known throughout the land for his beautiful wooden toys. Diego loved to watch his father work, and he dreamed of one day becoming just as skilled.

One day, Diego's father presented him with a special piece of wood, carved in the shape of a bird. "This is a very special piece of wood, my son," he said. "It has been passed down through our family for generations. It is said to hold the spirit of the condor, the greatest of all Andean birds. If you treat it with respect and care, it will one day help you to soar to great heights."

Diego was overjoyed and promised to take good care of the wooden bird. He kept it on his bedside table and would often talk to it, telling it about his dreams and aspirations.

As the years passed, Diego grew into a strong and capable young man. He learned his father's craft and became a skilled woodworker in his own right. But he never forgot about the wooden bird and the legend that surrounded it.

One day, Diego decided it was time to put the wooden bird to the test. He climbed to the top of the highest mountain in the Andes, the great Ausangate, and held the bird aloft, whispering a prayer to the spirits of his ancestors.

As he did so, the wooden bird began to glow with a warm, golden light. And then, to Diego's amazement, it began to grow and take on a life of its own. Before his very eyes, the wooden bird transformed into a magnificent condor, its wings spread wide and its feathers shimmering in the sun.

Diego climbed onto the condor's back and together they soared through the sky, high above the clouds. Diego felt a sense of freedom and joy like he had never experienced before. He saw the world in a way he never had before, and he knew that his dreams had come true.

From that day on, Diego became known as the greatest woodworker in the land, and the legend of the wooden bird lived on. And every night, before he went to bed, Diego would look at the wooden bird on his bedside table and smile, knowing that anything was possible if he believed in himself and his dreams.

The end.

Now my son, it's time to close your eyes, and dream big, who knows what kind of adventure awaits you. Good night.
